title: Elbow Region
raw_text:
ELBOW TENDINOPATHIES  (General Questions)



Age

What region is pain present in?

Shoulder

Clavicular region

Elbow

Do you have a recent history of fall or trauma in the affected region?

Yes

No

Was the pain onset sudden or gradual?

Sudden (Rule out rupture, link to avulsion of the biceps tendon)

Gradual

Do you experience tingling or abnormal sensations?

Yes

No

Do the following: lifting an object, repetitive wrist extension, gripping objects tightly, and twisting/rotating the forearm as in using a screwdriver or opening a door knob aggravate this pain? 

Yes

No

NB: If yes to 6, probe the following conditions.



LATERAL ELBOW TENDINOPATHY (aka Tennis Elbow or Lateral Epicondylitis)

Age (40 - 55)

Does your job or daily tasks involve repetitive forearm movement?

Yes

no

If yes, describe the level of your repetitive activities involving the forearm prior to this condition.

Low

Medium

High

Do your symptoms radiate to the forearm?

Yes

No

Do you experience early morning stiffness?

Yes

No

Do you experience weakness in the muscles of the forearm?

Yes

No

Do you experience discomfort during activities involving lifting, shaking of hands, and gripping?

Yes

No

Observation

Test:

Is palpation of the lateral epicondyle painful?

Yes

No



Provocative Tests

Maudsley’s test: Resisted extension of the middle finger elicits pain

Cozen’s test: Pain on resisted wrist extension

Mill’s Sign: Pt closes hands, dorsiflexes wrist and elbow is extended. The examiner then forces the wrist into palmar flexion against resistance; pain in the epicondyle is positive.





MEDIAL EPICONDYLITIS (Golfer’s Elbow)

Age (40 - 55)

Is tenderness present over the medial epicondyle?

Yes

No

Does your job or daily tasks involve repetitive forearm movement?

Yes

no

If yes, describe the level of your repetitive activities involving the forearm prior to this condition.

Low

Medium

High

Do your symptoms radiate to the forearm?

Yes

No

Do you experience early morning stiffness?

Yes

No

Do you experience weakness in the muscles of the forearm?

Yes

No

Do you experience discomfort during activities involving lifting and shaking of hands?

Yes

No

Observation

The patient resists forearm pronation with the forearm in extension.

Patient resists wrist flexion with the forearm in extension and supination (i.e. therapist resists wrist extension with the forearm in extension and supination)

The test is positive if pain is elicited.



Rule out ulnar nerve entrapment and medial ligament injury

For Ulnar Nerve Entrapment:

Do you experience pain, numbness or abnormal sensation in the forearm, fourth and ring finger?

Yes

No

Do you experience weakness of the hand muscles?

Yes

No (Could be both)

Check if muscle bulk in hand is normal (Extreme cases may include atrophy)



For Medial Ligament Injury:

Valgus Stress Test: Place forearm in supine position, flex elbow up till about 30 deg. Palpate MCL and apply lateral pressure (Abduction)Positive test: Increased laxity of MCL and pain.













DISTAL BICEPS TENDINOPATHY (Confirmation)

Age (40-59)

Do you exercise often by lifting weights? 

Yes

No



Observation

Check if pain is present on resisted forearm supination?

Pain indicates the presence of a biceps tendinopathy



AVULSION OF THE DISTAL BICEPS TENDON

Start from pain is sudden

Age (40s)

Did you perform any strenuous activity recently involving your forearm?

Yes

No

Do you feel weakness in the anterior portion of your forearm?

Yes

No

Did you feel a tearing sensation accompanying the pain onset?

Yes

No

Did you observe a shift in the position of the biceps belly?

Yes

No

Special Test:

O’Driscoll’s hook test: Palpate for biceps tendon in the antecubital fossa with arms flexed, shoulder ABducted and forearm in supination.

Test is positive if the biceps tendon cannot be hooked



OLECRANON BURSITIS (Student’s Elbow)

History of repeated pressure or friction to the olecranon?

Yes

No

Is olecranon region engorged?

Yes

No

If yes to 1 and 2, rule out rheumatoid arthritis. 



FOR RHEUMATOID ARTHRITIS

Is a nodule present at the back of the elbow?

Yes

No

Do you smoke?

Yes

No

Do you have episodes of fever that resolve spontaneously?

Yes

No

Is swelling present at the lateral aspect of the radio-humeral joint?

Yes

No

Do you experience pain (or tenderness) at the lateral aspect of the radiohumeral joint?

Yes

No

TEST

Check for osteopenia, bone erosions, destruction of the radial head and widening of the sigmoid notch.Other laboratories tests as may be necessary





FOR OSTEOARTHRITIS 

Age (60-69) and Male.

Do you work a manual job?

Yes

No

Have you had a previous history of fracture, dislocation, or gout?

Yes

No

Are extension and flexion movements limited at elbow?

Yes

No

Do you experience increasing limitations in performing self-care (styling hair, dressing, shaving)?

Yes

No

Do you experience pain in the lateral part of the elbow?

Yes

No

Is tenderness present around the joint?

Yes

No

Do you hear a crackling sound on moving the elbow?

Yes

No

TEST

Radiographic confirmation – Check for joint space narrowing, osteophyte formation, and subchondral sclerosis.
